description:
The Employment Subsidy Scheme, 2017, governed by the Goa State Incentives to Encourage Investments Scheme, 2017 (Umbrella Scheme), aims to incentivize local employment.  Key features include:

*   **Eligibility:** Micro, Small, Medium, and Large manufacturing industries (White, Green, and Orange categories) and Hinterland Eco-tourism projects in lesser developed talukas.
*   **Goan Manpower Requirement:** Enterprises must engage a minimum of 60% Goan manpower on regular employment. Employees on payroll continuously during the claim year are considered, with those earning a gross salary above Rs. 8,000 per month counted for subsidy calculation.
*   **Subsidy Period:** Up to seven years, subject to the Umbrella Scheme's conditions.
*   **Subsidy Calculation:**  Subsidy increases proportionally with Goan manpower from 60% to 100%. For Micro, Small, Medium enterprises and eco-tourism projects, the subsidy is calculated on 50% of total wages paid to eligible Goan employees, capped at Rs. 7,000 per employee per month and Rs. 25 lakh per annum. For large enterprises, it's based on 25% of wages, capped at Rs. 7,000 per employee per month and Rs. 50 lakh per annum.
*   **Claim Procedure:**  Claims must be submitted as per the Umbrella Scheme's timeline, including documents like registration proof, self-declaration, payroll details, Goan employee details, and Chartered Accountant certificates.

**Exclusions:**

*   Relations defined under Section 56 of the Income Tax Act 1961.
*   Units availing benefits under the Chief Minister's Rojgar Yojana (CMRY), other government employment schemes, or the Department of Information Technology's policies.
funding_pattern: Subsidy will be pro-rata increasing from 60% to 100% in a continuous linear scale subject to 60% to 80% of Goan employment.
title: EMPLOYMENT SUBSIDY SCHEME, 2017

description:
The Incentives to Industries for Training Prospective Employees Scheme, 2017, provides incentives to industries for training prospective employees.  Key features include:

*   **Eligibility:** Micro, small, medium, and large manufacturing enterprises registered under the umbrella scheme.
*   **Training Providers:** Courses must be conducted by approved Skill Training Providers (STPs) recognized by the Directorate of Technical Education (DTE), Directorate of Skill Development and Craftsmen Training (DSCT), and Directorate of Industries Trade & Commerce (DITC).
*   **Trainees:** Trainees must be Goan residents between 18 and 42 years old. Refresher or retraining courses are not eligible.
*   **Benefits:** Reimbursement of 60% of training costs, up to Rs. 60,000 per employee and Rs. 7,20,000 per unit per year.
*   **Application:** Submit an application to the Directorate of Industries Trade & Commerce with required documentation.

procedures.step_description: Employer submits a proposal for the training to the STP.
STP decides the course fees, which are paid by the employer.
Applicant submits an application to the Directorate of Industries Trade & Commerce along with required documentation.
Submit a self-declaration.
Provide a self-attested copy of registration under the Umbrella Scheme.
Submit a copy of the proposal given to the STP.
Provide a copy of approval given to the STP by DTE / DSCT / DITC.
Submit a certificate from the STP confirming successful course completion.
Provide a detailed report of the course conducted, along with the attendance roll, by the STP.
Submit a receipt of the fees paid.
Submit a Chartered Accountant certificate confirming that no other claim for similar benefit has been made under any other scheme/program of the Government of Goa.

funding_pattern: Reimbursement of 60% of training costs, up to Rs. 60,000 per employee and Rs. 7,20,000 per unit per year.
title: INCENTIVES TO INDUSTRIES FOR TRAINING PROSPECTIVE EMPLOYEES SCHEME, 2017

description:
incentivize units for making their enterprises financially viable.
Eligibility:
Micro, Small and Medium manufacturing industries listed under White, Green and Orange category, which have commenced production after 01/10/2017 are eligible.
The projects of Hinterland Eco tourism in lesser developed talukas registered with/ recognized by the Department of Tourism/ Goa IPB/ Town & Country Planning/PDA/Eco Sensitive Zone Authority will also be eligible to avail benefits under this scheme subject to fulfillment of all the other eligibility criteria.
        Enterprises engaging a minimum of 60% of Goan manpower on regular employment are eligible for benefits under this scheme. (for the purpose of this condition, employees who are employed continuously during the claim year and are on the payroll of the unit for that year shall be considered.)
        This Scheme is applicable to the enterprises which have availed loan as term loan and/or working capital loan for conducting business of the unit claiming the benefit, from any nationalized bank, scheduled private bank, Co-operative Bank, Economic Development Corporation Limited (EDC Ltd.) or any Non-Banking Financial Institutions recognized by the Reserve Bank of India and is restricted to interest paid to these organizations only.
        However, the loans of EDC Ltd., if covered under the Modified interest Rebate Scheme 2012, interest paid under Chief Minister Rojgar Yojan (CMRY) Scheme or and other employment generation scheme of Government of India/Government of Goa, units under Goa State Financial Relief Scheme for Sick Industrial Units, 2016, or any such scheme as well as charges/overdue and penal interest shall not be eligible for the purpose of this scheme.
        The enterprises which are taking or have taken any benefit under any policy of the Department of Information Technology, Government of Goa, shall not be eligible for benefits under this scheme.
        This scheme shall not be applicable to cases which have claimed similar benefit under any other scheme/program of Government of Goa.
Period of Subsidy:
For all the enterprises, the period of grant of subsidy shall not exceed seven years, that is 27 continuous quarters subsequent to the quarter in which the subsidy is first claimed.
Calculation of Subsidy:
For claims of interest paid on term loan, subsidy will be calculated to the extent of 30% of the interest paid, subject to ceiling under this scheme.
For claims of interest paid on working capital loan, subsidy will be calculated to the extent of 1 1/2% of the total turnover or 30% of the interest paid by the units/enterprise, whichever is less.
The subsidy will be pro rata increasing from 60% to 100% in a continuous linear scale subject to 60% to 80% of Goan employment.
Note: The quantum of benefit shall be defined by the proportion of Goan employees as follows:
Sr. Percentage of Goan Benefit No employees
Below 60% No benefit
60% 60%
>60% to <80% >60% to <100%
80% and above 100%
        The subsidy payable as calculated shall not exceed the ceiling of Rs. 25.00 lakh (27.50 lakh for all women and SC/ST applicants) per annum calculated on pro-rata basis for part of the year as claimed.
        The benefits under this scheme are subject to budgetary allocation. Promissory Estoppel shall be applicable if benefits are discontinued in case allocation is exceeded.
title: INTEREST SUBSIDY SCHEME, 2017

description: Increasing health consciousness and concern for environment is drawing attention to organic farming. Application of chemical pesticides is increasingly associated with the negative impact to human health and environment. There is a need to promote organic farming for healthy food, ecology and pollution free environment, while maintaining the soil and environment, with the process to reduce the dependence on harmful agro chemical and to supplement them with viable alternatives. Organic agriculture is a production system that sustains the health of soils, ecosy stem and people. It relies on ecological processes, biodiversity and cycles adapted to local conditions rather than the use of inputs with adverse effects. Organic agriculture combines tradition, innovation & service to benefit the shared environment and promotes fair relationships and a good quality of life for all involved.

description: The Western Ghat Development Programme (WGDP) has been implemented in Goa since 1975-76 to develop ecologically fragile areas. It was modified and notified in 2016-17 and further amended in 2021-22, focusing on five talukas: Sattari in North Goa, and Dharbandora, Sanguem, Quepem, and Canacona in South Goa. The scheme aims to develop soil and water conservation systems, create sustainable employment, introduce new agricultural technologies, and encourage the cultivation of diverse plant species.  Assistance is provided for basic activities like promotional meetings and training programs, maintenance of existing assets, production programs (planting materials, agro-processing units), and conservation programs (land development, trenches, gully control, bank stabilization, drain diversion, and dugout ponds).

procedures.step_description: Farmers/groups apply to the Zonal Agriculture Officer with the required forms and documents.
The Zonal Agriculture Officer scrutinizes the proposal and submits it to the Horticulture Section of the Directorate of Agriculture for approval.
Technical sanction is done by a Junior Engineer for certain activities.
Administrative approval is given by the Zonal Agriculture Officer or the Director of Agriculture depending on the scale of the activity.
Work is supervised by Zonal Agriculture Officer/Assistant Agriculture Officer and Junior Engineer.
After completion, inspection and completion reports are submitted.
Subsidy is disbursed by the Zonal Agriculture Officer.
Monthly progress reports are submitted to the Horticulture Section.

funding_pattern:
The funding pattern varies based on the specific activity. For example:

*   Basic Activities: Up to Rs. 20 per participant for refreshments in promotional meetings, and up to Rs. 200 per participant for training programs.
*   Maintenance of Assets: 10% of the evaluated cost of the structure.
*   Production Programs: Up to Rs. 5000/ha for planting materials, and up to 50% of the standard unit cost (limited to Rs. 30,000) for agro-processing and craft units.
*   Conservation Programs: Up to 50% of standard unit costs or actual costs depending on the specific activity (land development, trenches, gully plugging, bank stabilization, drain diversion, and dugout ponds).
title: Western Ghat Development Programme (WGDP)

description:
Addendum to the notification of State Sector Scheme "Assistance for Community Farming".

The following paras are added after para 4(A) x at page 1555 in Notification No. 3/2/1/CIN/Agron/CFG/D.Agri/447 dated 1st October, 2018 and published in Official Gazette, Series I No. 28 dated 11th October, 2018:

"The Community Farming Groups shall be eligible to create the agricultural infrastructure by availing 'At Source Subsidy' facility. In such cases the subsidy shall be paid to dealer/contractor/agencies who has provided the "At Source subsidy" facility to Community Farming Group provided that the Community Farmers Group pays their share of cost (cost of crating infrastructure minus the eligible subsidy) to dealer/contractor/agencies and furnish letter of Authority to that effect.

The Community Farming Group has to install/erects Solar power fencing, installation of water pumps, installation of micro irrigation and purchase of rnachmeries from the dealers registered with Directorate of Agriculture and who are willing to provide at. source facility for availing the subsidy.
Infrastructure such as digging & construction o[ well, installation/erection of barbed wire fencing, cl1ain link/wirernesh fencing, construction of stone wall fencing, water storage tank, compost unit, pump house, threshing/drying yards, repair/construction of non notified internal bund, drainage channels, and other agricultural infrastructure required for cultivation of crops can be created from any dealer/contractor/ agencies willing to provide facility of at source subsidy."

Other content of notification remains the same. The addendum shall come into force from the date of their publication in the Official Gazette.

The assistance for infrastructure will be limited to Rs. 2.50 lakhs per ha irrespective of area covered by the Farmers group.

description: Assistance for fencing scheme. Amendment of Assistance for fencing Scheme. Section 4A, clause (i) (b) shall be replaced as follows:- \"Assistance of 75%/90% for general category and SC/ST category respectively approved from time to \"The galvanized iron or synthetic chain link or wire mesh fencing\". Section 4A, clause (i) (c) shall be replaced as follows: \"Assistance @ 75%/90% for general category and SC/ST category respectively on standard cost as approved from time to time or actual cost whichever is less for Portion of stone Wall and chain link fence. After section 4A (iii) the following components as 4A(iv) Will be added: (iv) \"Hybrid Fence (combination of stone wall and solar power fencing or wire mesh/ /chain link fence)\". \"The hybrid fence will consist of stone Wall fence at base and solar power fence or galvanized iron or synthetic chain link or Wire mesh fencing erected above the stone Wall fence. \"The stone wall fence at base with foundation of minimum 0.3 m. depth and 0.5 mts. Width, 0.25 mts. width at the top and a height of 0.5 to 1.2 mts. above ground level constructed with available material like rubble/boulder, laterite - bricks river stones etc. above which the solar power fence or galvanized iron or synthetic chain link or wire mesh fencing may be erected. \"However, in case the basal portion minimum width shall be 15 ems. and minimum height 30 ems. above ground level''. \"The solar power fence will comprise of all components as eligible for solar power battery fence, with 3-7 lines of wire erected over the stone wall fence .

description:
Evaluate new varieties with improved yield and/or quality characters in farmer's fields.
Popularize improved varieties of food grain crops which are superior to existing varieties.
Identify varieties suitable for region specific problems such as pest/disease incidence etc.
Popularize labour and time saving cultivation techniques such as mechanized transplanting of paddy to increase net returns.
Propagate new cultivation techniques e.g. System of Rice Intensification (SRI) method and Aerobic cultivation in paddy etc., to increase productivity.

funding_pattern:
500/- subsidy limited to Rs. 1.00 lakh on purchase of trays/silpaulin sheets/sieves/wooden or metallic spacers for nursery blocks on silpaulin sheets etc. 
Two trainings of one day duration will be conducted. About 30 officials/farmers will be trained during each training. An amount of Rs. 10,000/- towards training aids, literature, working lunch & refreshments, P.O.L., honorarium to non-departmental resource persons including "farmer professors" etc., shall be spent for each batch of trainees.
Twenty two Field Days will be conducted in the State. A provision of Rs. 20,000/- will be made for each Field Day. 
A suitable manually operated weeder of cost limited to Rs. 2,000/- will be provided to each farmer cultivating SRI in a minimum of 0.1 ha area on a one time basis.
A manually operated sprayer with cost limited to Rs. 2,000/- will be provided to a group of minimum 10 farmers. 
Muriate of Potash fertilizer with cost lm11ted to Rs. 1,000/- per ha will be also provided on pro rata basis to farmers cultivating SRI m a minimum 1000 m2 area. This assistance will be restricted to cover 1000 hd in a year. Urea-DAP briquettes with cost limited to Rs. 4,500/- per ha will be provided to selected farmers having more than 0.1 ha under SRI to cover 50 ha area as per availability of briquettes. 
A monthly honorarium of Rs. 5,000/. will be paid to facilitators. Each such facilitator will cover an area of around 50 ha. Twenty-five facilitators will be nominated each year.

criteria.description: Units engaged in industrial, tourism related, service and commercial activities who have/had a good track record of loan repayment.

Satisfactory repayment history & past dealings of the promoters/unit/sister concerns/group concerns with the Corporation/Banks/FIs, with the loan account classified as standard for past two consecutive years with bank/financial institution in case of takeover of loans.
Borrower/applicant should be in operation for minimum five years and in cash profit for previous two financial years.
The proposed property to be mortgaged should not be presently leased out/rented out and should not be leased out/rented out in future without the permission of the Corporation.

Applicant should furnish all the required approvals and be agreeable to mortgage its immovable property as prime security and hypothecate its moveable assets with first charge to the Corporation or on pari-passu basis in case of consortium finance.

description: Policy Guidelines for reconsidering/re-validating One Time Settlement (OTS) offers for borrowers who accepted the offer but failed to make the payment. Aims to avoid prolonged legal processes and expenses.

procedures.step_description: Borrower/legal heirs submit a written request explaining reasons for non-payment.
Detailed information of borrower/legal heirs, including IT returns, P&L account, balance sheet, and net worth, is obtained, particularly for loans above Rs. 10 lakhs.
Borrower/promoters submit a sworn affidavit on their net worth, including details of personal assets.
Legal status of any existing cases is obtained.
Government directions on OTS schemes, CAG comments, and government approval for deviations are considered.
Re-validated settlement is discussed with the borrower and, if accepted, placed before the Competent Authority.
Earlier OTS offer is reworked and placed before the Competent Authority for approval.
Borrower makes settlement within 60 days, with a maximum delay of 90 days (15.5% interest for the extra 30 days).
Advance payment against original OTS and other payments are considered for the present settlement.
Deviations are recorded for consideration by the Competent Authority.
Cases above Rs. 10 lakhs are referred to the Government for approval.
Consolidated statement for loans below Rs. 10 lakhs is presented to the EDC Board for information.

title: Policy Guidelines for Reconsidering/Re-validating One Time Settlement (OTS) Offers

criteria.description: Applicable to borrowers who accepted OTS offers before 23.11.2015.
Borrowers who accepted OTS but failed to make payments.
Borrowers who made partial or total payments towards OTS with a delay.
Borrowers in a weak financial position or where the main borrower/partners/directors have expired.
Borrowers/legal heirs are not forthcoming or expressing inability to pay interest due on the delayed period or balance settlement amount.
OTS offers not withdrawn and accounts not closed.

SCHEME OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AGAINST MORTGAGE OF IMMOVABLE PROPERTIES
To provide financial assistance to existing units, with nil or nominal debt, to fund their projects for:

description: The District SPCAs of North and South Goa having their objectives for promotion of animal welfare and to protect animals from being subjected to unnecessary pain and suffering, are required to encourage the establishment of animal shelters, sanctuaries, water trough, and the likes for providing shelter and amenities to animals rescued from cruelty, incapacitated for work by reason of old age, sickness or injury. These animals are required to be given Veterinary Assistance with the help of Infirmaries and some of them may have to be rehabilitated at Animal Shelters.\nThe District SPCAs are also required to intervene in ABC programs, set targets, audit performance, and process applications for grants under available schemes of Animal Husbandry Department.

procedures.step_description: The District SPCAs North and South Goa, shall apply to the Directorate of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services in advance of every Financial Year for Grant in aid.
The Director AH&VS on due approval from the Government shall disburse the Grant in aid to the DSPCA in two yearly installments.
The Member Secretary DSPCA, will verify and certify the bills towards the cost of the components of the Grant in aid released in the first installment and submit an Utilization Certificate.
On subsequent release of the second installment of Grant in aid, the DSPCA on utilization of the Grant in aid shall submit the final Utilization Certificate and Audited Report.

description:
The District SPCAs of North and South Goa having their objectives for promotion of animal welfare and to protect animals from being subjected to unnecessary pain and suffering, are required to encourage the establishment of animal shelters, sanctuaries, water trough, and the likes for providing shelter and amenities to animals rescued from cruelty, incapacitated for work by reason of old age, sickness or injury. These animals are required to be given Veterinary Assistance with the help of Infirmaries and some of them may have to be rehabilitated at Animal Shelters. 
The District SPCAs are also required to intervene in ABC programs, set targets, audit performance, and process applications for grants under available schemes of Animal Husbandry Department. 
The DSPCAs so constituted are required to employ paid staff to manage the office and also to watch, warn or prosecute as required all persons guilty of cruelty to animals. Also to manage the ABC programme in the State. As such, they would require adequate financial support in terms of Man Power like Executive Secretary, DSPCA Inspectors, office staff, Accountant and a Legal council on a retainer basis to help achieve the basic functioning of the DSPCAs. 
Until such time the DSPCAs have their own infrastructure like building office, infirmary, animal shelter, and vehicles, they will have to rely on leasing out a suitable office premises and the assistance of Animal Welfare Organizations for Veterinary Assistance Shelter and Rehabilitation of the animals rescued. 
A provision is also required to be made to impart education in relation to the humane treatment of animals, build empathy, and encourage the formation of public opinions against the infliction of pain and suffering to animals.

title: DSPCA – Animal Welfare & Rescue Scheme
department_name: Department of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services

description: The objective of this scheme is to ensure that the investigation, prosecution and trial of criminal offences is not prejudiced because witnesses are intimidated or frightened to give evidence without protection from violent or other criminal recrimination. It aims to promote law enforcement by facilitating the protection of persons who are involved directly or indirectly in providing assistance to criminal law enforcement agencies and overall administration of Justice. Witnesses need to be given the confidence to come forward to assist law enforcement and Judicial Authorities with full assurance of safety. It is aimed to identify series of measures that may be adopted to safeguard witnesses and their family members from intimidation and threats against their lives, reputation and property.
funding_pattern: Budgetary allocation made in the Annual Budget by the State Government, Receipt of amount of costs imposed/ ordered to be deposited by the courts/ tribunals in the Witness Protection Fund, Donations/contributions from Charitable Institutions/Organizations and individuals permitted by Central/State Governments, Funds contributed under Corporate Social Responsibility

description: The scheme provides financial support to students of High Schools and Higher Secondary Schools in Goa to attend Science Seminars, Workshops, and Awareness Programmes in India. Each group can include a teacher for every five students.  The Goa State Council for Science & Technology (GSCST) implements the scheme, and maintains records of grant recipients and event details.

description:
The Government of Goa issued directives for Urban Co-operative Credit Societies, V.K.S.S. & Multipurpose Societies having Credit Counters:
1. Computerization: Adoption of suitable software linking branches with core banking, data storage measures, and websites disclosing financial information.
2. Interest for loans and deposits: Conformity with Nationalized Banks' interest rates with a variation limit of 2%.
3. Disclosure of financial results: Quarterly publication in newspapers, electronic dissemination to members, website disclosure of committee details, loan information, and other relevant data.
4. Verification of employees' antecedents: Compulsory verification and NOC requirement.
5. Management Board: Formation for societies with turnover from 10 to 100 crores, responsibilities include loan proposals, NPA recovery, fund management, and policy formulation.
6. Board of Directors resume and term: Conducting elections as per the Goa Co-operative Societies Act.
7. Registration of e-mail/mobile/whatsapps: Maintaining a database of contact information for electronic reporting.
8. "Fit and proper" criteria for CEO/Managing Director: Appointment process, qualifications, and experience requirements.
funding_pattern: Not specified
title: Directives for Urban Co-operative Societies in Goa

description:
Order
No. 5/24/Bye-Elections/ZPNS/2017-SEC/1309
Whereas the Bye-Elections to Zilla Panchayats of 9–Nuvem, 15–Curtorim in South Goa
Constituencies, 10–Calangute, 17–Corlim in North Goa Constituencies and Ward No. III of Village
Panchayat Morlem in Satari Taluka is scheduled on 20th August, 2017.
And whereas on the day of polling, the Presiding Officers are required to verify the identity of the elector with reference to his/her respective entry in the Voter’s List at the Polling Booth.
Now, therefore, as a necessary measure to avoid the malpractice of personation, and in exercise of Article 243K of the Constitution of India and Section 237 of Goa Panchayat Raj Act, 1994, read with Rule 34 of the Goa Panchayat and Zilla Panchayat (Election Procedure), Rules, 1996 the following documents are hereby prescribed as any one of which to be produced by the Elector at the Polling Booth;
1. Elector Photo Identity Card (EPIC) issued by the Election Commission of India.
2. Photo Identity Card issued by any Department of Central Government or State Government or any Government undertakings.
3. Smart Card or any other Photo Identity Card issued by the Government of India or Government of Goa.
4. Valid Driving License or Passport issued by Competent Authority.
5. PAN Card issued by Income Tax Department.
6. Pass Book of any Nationalized/Scheduled/ /Co-operative Bank containing Photograph of account holder with stamp of Bank.
7. Photo Identity Card issued by the Head of any Educational Institute recognized by Government of India or Government of Goa.
8. Aadhar Card.
9. Pension document with photographs.
10. Health insurance Smart card issued under the scheme of Ministry of Labour.
The Elector may produce any one of the above listed documents to establish his/her identity at the Polling Booth;
It is further clarified that in case of unclear photos or mismatch of photo on the EPIC/Voters slip issued by Election Commission of India, the issue of Ballot paper shall not be refused merely on the ground of unclear photo or mismatch of photo if the identity of the Elector is otherwise established.
The Returning Officer shall provide a copy of the this Order to all the Presiding Officers for their training at Taluka level.
funding_pattern: unspecified
title: Bye-Elections to Zilla Panchayats

description: Assistance for construction of retaining wall for soil conservation.

procedures.step_description: The interested farmers shall submit his application indicating approximate length and height of proposed retaining wall before commencement of work.

The farmer should also submit a photo before the commencement of work with at least one natural reference point in the photograph i.e. structure like wall, boundary stone, trees etc. to co-relate the site, while giving the administrative approval.
He should also produce the photograph after the completion of work with same reference point in the picture given above.

The Zonal Agriculture Officer (Z.A.O.)/District Agriculture Office (DAO) (North/South) would scrutinize the proposal on receipt of all the relevant documents and inspect the site and issue administrative approval accordingly.
The farmer after completion of the structure in all respect shall report to the Z.A.O. and submit all relevant expenditure bills/vouchers to Z.A.O. for claiming assistance.
The Z.A.O. will then inspect the claim and cases completed in all respect will be forwarded to District Agriculture Office for the settlement of claim.

funding_pattern: 50% of cost for construction of retaining wall of average width of 0.4 mt and height upto 1.5 mts.
title: Assistance for construction of retaining wall for soil conservation

procedures.step_description: The beneficiary shall possess the NOC issued by the Directorate of Fisheries for the procurement of FRP Fishing Craft up to 10 meter OAL as a replacement of old wooden canoe and purchase of fishing net and insulated fish and ice holding boxes.

The beneficiary shall produce the original GST bill from the authorized dealer towards the purchase/construction of new canoe, Gill net and its accessories and insulated fish and ice holding box to claim the subsidy.
The applicant shall not be fishing trawler owner and defaulter of Department.

description:
The main reason for the success of the dairy programme in India is the involvement of milk producers in setting up their own organizations for milk production enhancement, milk procurement, processing and marketing.  Dairying as a subsidiary source of income, is a real relief to most of these weaker groups in society. The Dudh Gram Villages shall be carved out, based on their records of supply of maximum milk produced in a year and supplied to the Goa Milk Producers’ Union and other authorized Agencies. The concept is to target these groups and attain faster results in these Villages/Gram Panchayats to be declared as Dudh Gram in the implementation of Milk Policy for the State with the intention of giving special attention in the policy and programme implementation.
Objectives of the scheme.— The main objectives of the scheme are:
v To help the farmers to get financial assistance for the purchase of cross bred cows, improved she buffaloes and cows of indigenous breeds namely Sahiwal, Gir and Red Sindhi for his Dairy Unit.
v To promote self employment in the Dairy Sector.
v To boost the milk production in the State and to make State self sufficient.
v To strengthen the Dairy Co-operative movement in the State.
v To ensure sustainability and provide improved income and livelihood.
v To also encourage the Scheduled Tribes and Scheduled Caste Communities.
v To create employment in the State.
Eligibility:
Ø Any person residing in Goa for at least 05 years or more.
Ø Knowledge or experience in cattle or buffaloes farming.
Ø Land for green fodder cultivation desirable.
Ø Farmer who had availed the purchase of animals under the earlier Kamdhenu Scheme.
Ø Applicant should necessarily have a cattle shed to undertake the scheme.
funding_pattern:

description: The Goa government has formulated a Self Certification Scheme for factories, shops, and commercial establishments. The scheme, effective from the date of online application, aims to simplify labor law enforcement and create a business-friendly environment. Establishments opting for the scheme will undergo fewer inspections. Key features include online application, a one-time registration fee based on the number of laborers, and a validity period of five years. The scheme covers various labor laws, but high-risk industries are excluded. Applications are accepted annually from January 1st to March 31st.

procedures.step_description: Apply online at the Labour Department website (www.goaonline.gov.in).
Pay the one-time registration fee, which varies based on the number of employees.

description:
Financial Assistance to Dairy Farmers belonging to Scheduled Tribes and Scheduled Caste for purchase of basic dairy equipments.

Objectives:
1. To provide assistance to the Scheduled Tribes and Scheduled Caste communities for purchase of basic dairy equipments needed to run a small scale dairy farming.
2. To encourage the tribal population to adopt Animal Husbandry activities especially Dairy Development Schemes.

Eligibility: Any farmer belonging to Scheduled Tribes/Scheduled Caste Community.

Procedure for Application: The farmer shall apply on a prescribed application form in duplicate and submit it through the local Veterinary Officer/Assistant Director along with the following documents:

(a) Caste Certificate issued by Competent Authority.
(b) Aadhar Consent Form duly filled in.
(c) 5 years residential certificate.
(d) 2 passport size photograph of the Applicant.
(e) Prescribed Affidavit duly notarised.
(f) Copy of Ration Card.
(g) Copy of Bank pass book.

No processing fee shall be charged under this scheme.
The concerned Officer shall scrutinize the application and forward it to the Directorate of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services, Patto-Panaji within 15 days of its receipt with his/her recommendation.

procedures.step_description: Apply on a prescribed application form in duplicate.
Submit the application through the local Veterinary Officer/Assistant Director.
Submit required documents.
The concerned Officer scrutinizes the application and forwards it to the Directorate of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services within 15 days.
The application will be further processed at Directorate and will be approved if found in order.
On approval, the beneficiary shall submit the original purchase receipts or bills within 90 days.
The bills will be verified, certified after inspection of the equipments and submitted to Head Office or release of subsidy.
The Departments will release the subsidy within 60 days.

funding_pattern: 100% subsidy shall be provided for dairy items of general use of a Dairy farmer subject to a maximum of Rs. 30,000/- or actual cost of the items whichever is lower.
title: Financial Assistance to Dairy Farmers belonging to Scheduled Tribes and Scheduled Caste for purchase of basic dairy equipments

criteria.description: The applicant/farmer should have at least two milch animals (Local Cows/Indigenous cows/Cross Bred cows/Local Buffaloes/Improved Buffaloes).
Applicant should be resident of state of Goa for at least five preceding years.
The applicant should not have availed subsidy under any scheme of Government of Goa for any of the equipments applied under this scheme.

description:
The Goa Rehabilitation Scheme, 2007

**Definitions:**

*   **Act:** The Goa Rehabilitation Board Act, 2006 (Goa Act 9 of 2006)
*   **Allotment:** Allotment of shelter from the stock of shelters by the board, by a letter of grant, to the displaced person.
*   **Board:** The Goa Rehabilitation Board established under section 3 of the Act.
*   **Displaced person:** A person who lost his house in the land slide that occurred on 14th June, 1999, at Tariwada in ward No. 3 of Mormugao Municipal Council and who is in need of a shelter.
*   **Order of grant:** The Order issued permitting occupation and use of a shelter on terms and conditions as mentioned thereof.
*   **Shelter:** A residential unit constructed or got constructed by the Board in the property bearing Chalta No. 2 (part) of P. T. Sheet No. 52, situated at Sada, Vasco da Gama, Mormugao-Goa.
*   Words and expression used but not defined in this Scheme shall have the same meaning as assigned to them in the Act.

**Preparation of list of displaced person:**

1.  The Deputy Collector, Mormugao, having jurisdiction over the area where the land slide has occurred shall prepare a list of displaced persons within 30 days from the receipt of such request from the Board.
2.  The Deputy Collector thereafter shall cause the said list to be published in three local newspapers in Konkani, Marathi and English languages and allow a period of 7 days to the displaced persons to verify the said list and submit any representation thereof.
3.  The Deputy Collector shall then finalize the said list and forward the same to the Board; the Board may either accept as final the list as submitted by the Deputy Collector or modify the list after giving an opportunity of being heard to any displaced person.

**Allotment of shelters:**

1.  The Board shall by means of a lot allocate the shelter available in its stock to the displaced persons going by the serial order in the list.
2.  The Member Secretary of the Board shall thereafter intimate the displaced person the intention of the Board to allot the shelter and shall call upon the said displaced person to state whether he is ready and willing to accept the said shelter upon terms and conditions laid down by the Board.
3.  In case the displaced person conveys his acceptance thereof to the Member Secretary, he shall, with the concurrence of the Board issue an order of grant to the affected person if the displaced person does not accept the initial offer made by the Board or fails to take possession of shelter after issuing order of grant on the appointed date, the displaced person shall lose his right to be rehabilitated under this Scheme or any other Scheme framed by the Board.
4.  The Board, while considering the grant of shelter to the displaced person shall take into consideration their economic condition hardships caused to them, in society, and other aspects.
5.  The cost of the shelter along with all other amenities shall be calculated and the same shall be taken into consideration while fixing any rents required to be paid by the displaced person in the manner laid down in the C PWD code for leasses to economically weaker section of the society.
6.  The Board may, in exceptional circumstances, exempt any particular displaced person from paying rent whose head of the family is a widow or getting assistance under the Dayanand Social Security, Scheme, and/or would be so entitled under any Central or State Government Scheme, provided that the appropriate Government in relation to that scheme makes a matching contribution to the Board.
7.  The displaced person upon acceptance and taking possession of the shelter shall observe and follow all the terms and conditions incorporated in the Order of grant and for any breach of such terms or conditions the Board shall take such action against the displaced person as it deems fit.

beneficiaries.beneficiary_type: A person who lost his house in the land slide that occurred on 14th June, 1999, at Tariwada in ward No. 3 of Mormugao Municipal Council and who is in need of a shelter

description:
Community Dairy Farming Scheme (Amended 2021)
Introduction.— Government has noticed that the small units of around 10 cow dairy farms are not much profitable to take up as a business entrepreneur. The farmers with limited land holding also find it difficult to expand the existing units due to scarcity of land and other infrastructure requirements.
After going through the feasibility of the schemes, a concept of community dairy farming has been under consideration for long time to facilitate group of people coming together with a common intention to take up dairy farming on a community basis with common infrastructure support.
Therefore it is proposed to encourage such Community Dairy farming with minimum 50 milch animals and with latest ultra modern dairy equipments such as milk parlour, milk cooler and feed mixing plant etc. which can be availed by community group of minimum 5 members.
funding_pattern: Subsidy limited to maximum of Rs. 1.75 crore at the rate of 50% of permissible unit cost (component wise). Transport cost of animals and Insurance Premium will be given 100% of unit cost.
title: Community Dairy Farming Scheme (Amended 2021)
department_name: Department of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services

description: The Community Dairy Farming Scheme, amended in 2021, encourages groups of farmers to establish larger dairy units with shared infrastructure.  This scheme aims to improve profitability, reduce production costs, and promote dairy farming as a sustainable industry in Goa. Key features include financial assistance for infrastructure development, purchase of milch animals, and dairy equipment. Eligibility requirements include group registration, land ownership or lease agreement, and residency in Goa.

beneficiaries.beneficiary_type: Farmers/groups with minimum five unrelated members

procedures.step_description: Apply through Area Assistant Director/Veterinary Officer with a non-refundable processing fee of Rs. 500/-
Complete the sanctioned project within one year of sanction.
Purchase milch animals only after completing the farm infrastructure.
Purchase animals from Cattle Mela held at Govt. Livestock Farms or from outside the state (transit insurance is mandatory for out-of-state purchases).
Insure the purchased animals for a minimum of 42 months and identify them through microchipping/ear tagging.
Upon completion, the Area Veterinary Officer/Asst. Director submits documents to the Directorate of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services through the Financing Institution.
Submit an agreement bond sworn before a Notary/Magistrate.
The Area Veterinary Officer/Asst. Director inspects and recommends the purchase of milch animals if satisfied with the infrastructure and fodder arrangements.

title: Community Dairy Farming Scheme
funding_pattern: Subsidy Limited to maximum of Rs. 1.75 Crore at the rate of 50% of permissible unit cost (component wise). Transport cost of animals and Insurance Premium will be given 100% of unit cost
documents: Documents indicating the ownership of land in Form No. I & XIV/ Sale deed or copy of notarized lease deed or legitimized NOC from Land owner for a period of 12 years
NOC and construction license from prescribed authority.
Certificate of registration of the group from competent authority (Registrar of Co-operative Society)
Letter from the Financing Institution having ECS system, willing to finance the beneficiary.
Residence Certificate of each member issued by competent authority (preceding 05 years ).
Consent for seeding and authentication of Aadhar / UID number
Certificate of practical training in dairy management (of all the members)
Passport size photograph of each applicant
Survey site plan/plan of the cattle shed, Store room and other infrastructure proposed at the said unit of community dairy
Notarised authority from group members to the leader of the group.
Annexure showing the details of the group members.

criteria.description: Any group having minimum 05 members and registered with competent authority ( Registrar of Co-operative Society)

May desirably possess irrigated land for Green Fodder Cultivation or use other alternatives like silage, hydroponic etc as a source of fodder, in addition to the area for infrastructure developments of minimum 10000 sq. Mts.
The scheme is applicable for new unit and expansion of the existing Community Dairy
Each member of the group shall be resident of Goa for at least preceding five years with experience in dairy management/ Practical training for 15 days in dairy management

description: A Scheme to open the Labour Welfare Centres was launched by the Government of Goa in 1969 to impart training in Embroidery Cutting and Tailoring. Since then a chain of Labour Welfare Centres were opened throughout the State. The Government however, recently after the report of the work study has banned further opening of the L.W.C’s. The requirement however from the areas with labour concentration continues. To meet the requirements of the Industrial class, the Board considered it expedient to start its own scheme.

procedures.step_description: Syllabus of the scheme shall be designed on the course conducted by the Office of the Commissioner, Labour& Employment and the State Directorate of Craftsmen’s Training.
Appointment of Sewing Mistress shall be on Part-Time basis / Daily Wages / Regular Basis depending upon the needs and circumstances.
Timing of the L.W.C’s shall be from 9.30 am to 1.15 pm, (Morning Batch) and 2.00 p.m. to 5.45 p.m (Evening Batch).
Admission of trainees with contagious diseases shall be strictly prohibited.
Examination for the trainees shall be conducted in collaboration.

description: This scheme aims to provide sanitary napkin vending machines and incinerators in industrial units and schools/colleges for female industrial workers and their daughters studying from class VII onwards. The biggest barrier to using sanitary napkins is affordability. The scheme, called \"STRI SAKHI SCHEME\", will procure and install the machines, especially in industrial estates with a higher concentration of women. The management of the industrial unit/school/college will be responsible for the upkeep and replenishment of the vending machines. The machines will be coin-operated (Re. 1), and the collected money can be used to purchase sanitary pads. The Goa Labour Welfare Board will bear the cost of installation and replenishment for schools/colleges and small industrial unit clusters.

beneficiaries.beneficiary_type: Daughters of female industrial workers studying from class VII onwards

Sign a Memorandum of Understanding with the Goa Labour Welfare Board for installation and upkeep of the machine.
Maintain the machines in good working condition at all times.
Replenish the vending machine periodically so that it does not run out of stock.
Maintain a register showing the amount collected and amount spent every month.

funding_pattern: The Goa Labour Welfare Board will bear the cost of installation and replenishment for schools/colleges and small industrial unit clusters. For industrial units, the cost of replenishment will be borne by the management.

description: SCHEME FOR EXCURSION-CUM STUDY TOURS FOR THE WORKERS/EMPLOYEES EMPLOYED AT VARIOUS INDUSTRIAL ESTALISHMENTS\nExcursion-cum-study Tours of the workers / employees engaged in the various Industrial establishments will provide an opportunity to visit various important Industrial, historical and religious places in the Country and broaden their out-look.

procedures.step_description: The management will submit the proposal to the Secretary through the subordinate officers concerned in the enclosed form ‘A’.
The Secretary in turn will examine the proposal and place the same before the Advisory Committee nominated by the Board for approval.
If recommended by the Advisory Committee, the Secretary will sanction the tour subject to the conditions laid down in the scheme.
On receipt of the sanction, the management should work out the itinerary of the tour with definite date of tour etc. and obtain prior approval of the Secretary before the tour is undertaken.
The Management will, in first instance, incur the expenditure and then claim reimbursement of admissible amount from the Secretary.

title: SCHEME FOR EXCURSION-CUM STUDY TOURS FOR THE WORKERS/EMPLOYEES EMPLOYED AT VARIOUS INDUSTRIAL ESTALISHMENTS
funding_pattern: 50% bus hire charges, daily allowance paid to the workers during the tour will be Rs. 50 per day per worker, emergent postal telegram and telephone charges maximum of Rs. 200 per tour, insurance cover premium should not exceed Rs. 10 per worker.

criteria.description: His / her name is in the wage register and has put in continuous service of at least two years.
He / she should actually be an employee of Industrial establishment on the relevant date tour and should be in possession of identity card.
His / her monthly earning should not exceed Rs. 2,600/- (Rupees Two Thousand Six Hundred Only) per month.
The workers / employees who have once availed themselves of the facilities under the scheme shall not be eligible for such benefit for the next 4 years from the date of completion of the tour.

description: SCHEME FOR T.B. DOMICILIARY TREATMENT OF EMPLOYEES COVERED UNDER THE GOA LABOUR WELFARE FUND ACT, 1986.\n Domiciliary treatment for recoupment is very essential, as hospitalization for a longer period is not considered necessary.\nEmployees/workers who have been advised domiciliary treatment shall be eligible for facilities under the scheme for a period not exceeding nine months or till the date of issue of fitness certificate whichever is earlier.
funding_pattern: Treatment charges not exceeding Rs. 300/- p.m. to each worker. Payment of subsistence allowance subject to a maximum of Rs. 1000/- p.m. where the worker is the only earning member with no other income and Rs. 400/- p.m. where dependents are more than one.
title: SCHEME FOR T.B. DOMICILIARY TREATMENT OF EMPLOYEES

criteria.description: Workers suffering from T.B. and undergoing domiciliary treatment through approved dispensaries

description: SCHEME FOR SUPPLY OF T.V SETS TO INDUSTRIAL ESTABLISHMENTS/LABOUR WELFARE CENTRES/CLUBS/RECREATION ROOMS.With the linking of various places in the country with the Television network, it has become essential to provide T.V. sets to the Industrial Establishments, Labour Welfare Centres/Clubs/Recreation Rooms for the benefits of the workers employees engaged in various industries. By providing T.V. Sets, the workers/employees will be able to witness programmes of national importance and inculcate in themselves ideas of national integration besides broadening their outlook.

procedures.step_description: Submit an application form in triplicate.

The management /Union/Government shall enter into an agreement with the Welfare Board to maintain the T.V. Set in good working condition at all times and exhibit programmes for the benefit of their workers on day-to-day basis.

funding_pattern: The Welfare Fund will purchase colored T.V. sets (cost not exceeding Rs. 25,000) or reimburse the full cost of Black and White T.V. sets (up to Rs. 12,000).
title: SCHEME-IV SCHEME FOR SUPPLY OF T.V SETS TO INDUSTRIAL ESTABLISHMENTS/ LABOUR WELFARE CENTRES/CLUBS/RECREATION ROOMS.

criteria.description: Industrial establishments, Labour Welfare Centres run by Government of Goa and clubs, recreation rooms run by registered trade unions having minimum members of 300 workers. Preference shall be given to applicants having place of entertainment in labour concentrated areas.

description:
The scheme aims to provide recreational opportunities for industrial workers and employees, along with their families, through sports, games, social, and cultural activities. These activities serve as a means of mental and physical rejuvenation, promoting good human relations and offering respite from monotonous work routines.  The scheme can be implemented by the Secretary, through staff, subsidies to management or reputable social and cultural organizations, or through voluntary organizations like workers' recreation clubs.

Activities include popular outdoor/indoor sports, games, and cultural events. Social activities encompass national and regional festival celebrations, and important national events.  Events are located in areas with a concentration of 1000 or more industrial workers/employees.

Expenditure can cover sports articles and equipment, cultural activities, refreshments, prizes, arrangements, and social events. Total annual expenditure for an area with 10,000 or more workers/employees should not exceed Rs. 20,000, subject to budget provisions.

If the Welfare Board holds the event, the Secretary must obtain sanction, justifying the event and expenditure items.  If management or a voluntary organization arranges the event, the Secretary reimburses 50% of the cost, up to Rs. 5,000 per event, after approval.  Post-event, the organizers submit a claim with details of the event, participants, original bills, participant acknowledgements, stamped receipts, and a report.

procedures.step_description: Obtain sanction from the Goa Labour Welfare Board for events held by the board
Submit claim with details of the event, participants, original bills, participant acknowledgements, stamped receipts, and a report for events held by management or voluntary organizations

funding_pattern: The total expenditure for an area with 10,000 or more workers should not exceed Rs. 20,000. The Welfare Board reimburses 50% of the cost up to Rs. 5,000 per event organized by other entities.
title: SCHEME FOR ORGANISING SPORTS GAMES SOCIAL AND CULTURAL ACTIVITIES FOR INDUSTRIAL WORKERS / EMPLOYEES

description: Scheme to pay incentives to the wards of workers on the basis of percentage of marks obtained by them on passing final examination conducted by the Boards/Universities from class X onwards.

beneficiaries.beneficiary_type: Wards of workers/employees employed in the State of Goa

procedures.step_description: The eligible students should submit their application in the prescribed proforma as per Annexure I (enclosed) to their respective Heads of Educational Institutions where they are studying along with attested copy of Marksheet and Certificate of employment from the management where their parents are employed.

After receipt of applications from the eligible students, the respective Heads of Educational Institutions shall forward all the applications along with the separate statement as prescribed in Annexure II for each class-wise to this office within one month from the date of announcement of the results by the Board/Universities.

funding_pattern: Not specified

description: The scheme provides medical / monetary relief to the children of the Industrial Workers covered under the Goa, Daman and Diu Labour Welfare Act, 1986. The assistance is to look after the child who is mentally challenged and suffering from spasticity fully dependent upon the parents / guardians for all day to day activities for which a normal child of that age does not need such assistance.

procedures.step_description: For re-imbursement of expenditure for treatment, an application in the prescribed Form ‘A’ should be submitted by the workers to the Secretary though his employer duly certified by the competent Medical authorities of the Hospital.
Submit yearly alive certificate.

funding_pattern: Subsistence allowance @ Rs. 3000/- p.m. where the worker (a) happens to be the only earning member of the family and (b) has no other source of income during the period of treatment of his child.
title: SCHEME FOR TREATMENT OF MENTALLY CHALLENGED AND SPASTIC CHILDREN OF INDUSTRIAL WPRKERS

criteria.description: A worker who has put in at least six months of continuous service irrespective of any pay limit.

The child should be certified as mentally challenged to the extent that it necessitates parental assistance by the Institute of Psychiatry in case of mentally challenged and in case of the child suffering from spasticity it should certified by the Orthopaedic Surgeon / Physician of Asilo Hospital, Mapusa / Goa Medical College, Panaji or Hospicio, Margao.

description: Scheme to provide financial assistance to female students studying in classes V and onwards. Assistance is based on school attendance.

beneficiaries.beneficiary_type: Female students studying in classes V and onwards, daughters of workers/employees

procedures.step_description: Obtain application form (Annexure-1).
Get the form authenticated by the Head of the Institution.
Submit the application to the Secretary, Goa Labour Welfare Board by 30th September.

funding_pattern: ECS transfer to parents' bank account once a year.

criteria.description: Either parent should be a worker/employee for at least six months.
Family income from all sources should not exceed Rs.20,000/- p.m. (includes income of father, mother, and unmarried siblings).
Daughters of supervisory staff are not eligible.
Students receiving incentives from other similar schemes will be granted an incentive only if the Fund's incentive exceeds the other scheme's amount.

description:
Indira Gandhi National Old Age Pension Scheme is a 100% Central Scheme covering the beneficiaries residing in rural areas and also from urban area comesunderBPL category.
Under this programme, pension of Rs.200/- per month to Senior Citizen and Rs.300/- per month to Disabled & Widow is provided to the beneficiaries of 60 years of age and above till the age of 79 years and thereafter Rs.500/-. The beneficiary must be a destitute in the sense of having little or no regular means of subsistence from his/her own source of income or through financial support from family members or other sources. This scheme had been transferred to Directorate of Social Welfare along with the list of the beneficiaries. However, the pension of Rs.300/- to Rs.500/- per month is being given to the beneficiaries by the grant- in- aid, to Directorate of Social Welfare by thisAgency. TheCategory wise breakupof thePension isas follows:-
Category Age Group Amount(Rs.)
60-79 200
Old agePension
80+ 500
DisabledPersons 18-79 300
Pension 80+ 500
40-79 300
WidowsPension
80+ 500
funding_pattern: 100% Central Scheme
title: Indira Gandhi National Old Age Pension Scheme (IGNOAPS)

description: The Beti Bachao Beti Padhao Scheme (BBBP) is a Central Sector Scheme implemented through State Governments/UTs to empower the girl child and enable her education. This scheme is intended to improve Child sex ratio across the country. This scheme seeks to address the issue of decline in child sex ratio across the country targeted at changing societal mindset and creating awareness. The scheme aims at preventing gender biased sex selective elimination, ensuring survival and protection of the girl child and ensuring education and participation of the girl child.

description: The Bursary Scheme provides financial assistance towards fees paid for various courses under Higher and Technical Education in Goa.  It aims to make higher education accessible to a wider range of students by offering financial support based on need and merit.

beneficiaries.beneficiary_type: Students pursuing College (Higher and Professional) Education in the State of Goa including post graduation

procedures.step_description: Eligible students submit applications with required documents to the Head of the Institution within 15 days of the academic year commencement.
The Head of the institution scrutinizes applications and submits a consolidated list to the Goa Education Development Corporation within 45 days of the course commencement.
The Goa Education Development Corporation places applications before the committee for sanction within 30 days of receipt.
The amount is transferred to the student's account under Direct Benefit Transfer.

The annual income of both parent(s)/guardian taken together is less than Rupees three lakhs.

description: The scheme aims to provide counseling services to students in government and government-aided secondary and higher secondary schools to address emotional, psychological, and socio-economic challenges. Workshops and awareness programs are conducted for students, teachers and parents. Financial assistance is given to eligible counselors and supervisors.

procedures.step_description: The eligible institutions willing to avail the loan facility shall apply to the Directorate of Higher Education giving all the details as required under the scheme.

title: SOFTLOAN SCHEME\nSCHEME FOR SOFT LOAN TO THE GRANT-IN-AID/ NON-GRANT IN AID INSTITUTIONS FOR MAINTENANCE AND UPGRADATION OF INFRASTRUCTURE FACILITIES.
funding_pattern: 50% of the loan amount shall be released immediately on the issue of sanction order by the Directorate of Higher Education. 40% of the loan amount shall be released on the production of a certificate from Government Registered Engineer duly signed by a Chartered Accountant (C.A.) and College Principal/Head of Institution; to the effect that the first installment of 50% has been fully utilized for the purpose for which it was granted. The balance 10% of the loan amount shall be released subject to the following: Production of the similar certificate to the effect that 40% of the loan amount has been fully utilized for the purpose for which it was granted. The project is completed and a completion certificate to that effect is produced by the Management. The occupancy certificate issued by a competent authority to the satisfaction of the Directorate of Higher Education.

criteria.description: The society which runs the institution should have been registered under the Societies Registration Act.

The institution seeking the loan should meet any one of the following requirements: The institutions concerned should be affiliated to Goa University. The institutions should have been recognized by AICTE/MCI/ACI/DCI or any other statutory body of the Government of India/Government of Goa.
The institution should have been in operation for at least 10 years preceding the date of application of loan.
The institution should have minimum strength of 300 students on the campus.
The average passing percentage should not be below 60% in last three years out of five years immediately preceding the date of application for loan.

documents: Cost estimate of the project duly certified by a Registered Engineer and Chartered Accountant
Latest audited statements of accounts of the institution
Documents of the sale deed/long lease deed or any other documents which indicates the ownership of the land where the building will stand

description: Revised Scheme to finance in the form of loan, to the Government Aided Educational Institutions for the purpose of their upkeep and maintenance and upgrade the existing facilities. (Infrastructure Loan cum Grant Scheme). The loan is meant for the improvement of infrastructure like construction/renovation of school building, toilets/bathroom, Hostel facilities, construction of playground and to purchase equipment for security of the school including CCTV. It also includes the cost of land for the purpose of construction of School building and playground only but not exceeding 50% of the total loan amount with prior permission of the Department. The expenditure on salary, consumables like chalks, dusters, laboratory material like glass, plastic, chemicals is however not covered. Items admissible under non salary grant will not be covered.

procedures.step_description: The school managing committee shall submit the report comprising utilization certificate, countersigned by Chartered Accountant, physical inspection and progress report countersigned by Registered Engineer.

GSIDC will inspect the site in building and evaluate the value and quality of the work done and compliance with the scheme and submit its report within a period of one month from receipt of reports from Directorate of Education.

All proposals under the scheme shall be scrutinized by a committee constituting the Director of Education, Additional Director of Education, Representative of GEDC, Representative of Secretary (Finance), Joint Director of Accounts of Directorate of Education as members.

funding_pattern: Loan-cum-Grant
title: Revised Infrastructure Loan cum Grant to Educational Institution

The Educational Institutions should be at least of 5 years old from the date of recognition.

description: The scheme aims to implement yoga education in government primary schools to foster overall personality development and address issues like stress, attention deficit, and behavioral problems among students. It involves training teachers and adopting NCERT-approved syllabus with specially developed yoga books.

procedures.step_description: Constitution of a state-level Yog cell of Yog experts.
Identification and training of 60 Master Resource Persons by experts from Haridwar University.
Training of 152 Government Primary Teachers by Master Resource Persons.
Adoption of NCERT-approved syllabus and Patanjali Yog peeth books.
Implementation in approximately 240 Govt. Primary schools for the Academic year 2017-18 and training of 229 Government Primary teachers at the Taluka level from 8th to 16th January 2018.
Implementation in approximately 240 Govt. Primary schools for the Academic year 2018-19.

funding_pattern: The scheme is implemented through Goa Education Development Corporation. Funding pattern is not clearly specified but implies support for 100 such schools.

description:
Enhancing Civic Engagement

Objective:
As per the mandate given by the Government of Goa by the Hon’ble Chief Minister, it was decided that Shantilal Muttha Foundation (SMF) created additional interventions for two high priority areas namely: Sanitation, Hygiene & Waste Management and (ii) Traffic Awareness and Road Safety. These interventions are to be offered from primary to secondary grades. 
Two themes, three working groups (WGs) were constituted for: (1) Sanitation & Hygiene (ii) Waste Management (iii) Traffic Awareness & Road Safety
• WG1 (Sanitation & Hygiene)
• WG2 (Waste Management)
• WG3 (Traffic Awareness & Road Safety)

procedures.step_description: The whole programme was planned by Shantilal Muttha Foundation and approved by the Workgroups under the Civic Engagement Committee. The Directorate of Education, SCERT, Goa and GEDC selected 23 Government Primary Schools and 11 Secondary Schools for implementation of Civic Engagement on pilot basis for the year 2017-18. The syllabus and report in respect of all the workgroups was submitted by Shantilal Muttha Foundation on 14th December 2017 for approval. On 21st December the review was taken by Workgroup under Civic Engagement Committee, Master Trainers ( 23 Primary Teachers & 11 Secondary Teachers) and staff of Shantilal Muttha Foundation.
On 7th January 2018 Shantilal Muttha Foundation submitted revised Enhancement Civic Engagement books to SCERT for final approval.
From 17th to 25th January 2018 training was given to Teachers from selected 23 Government Primary Schools and 11 Secondary Schools for implementation on ECE programme on trial basis.
The implementation of Civic Engagement programme started on trial basis from 29th January 2018 to 15th March in the selected schools.

A meeting was held on 12th February 2018 at SCERT, under the Chairmanship of Shri Shripad Patnekar, Chairman GEDC to take the review and for preparation of future plan. It was decided in the meeting to implement the Civic Engagement Scheme in selected 52 Government Primary Schools, 26 Government Secondary Schools and 24 Aided Secondary Schools on pilot basis for the Academic Year 2018-19.

funding_pattern: The financial matter will be dealt by GEDC.
title: Enhancing Civic Engagement

description:
Mulyavardhan (MV) is a value education programme to help children imbibe democratic values, attitudes and skills in an enabling school environment. Mulyavardhan was initiated in 2009 and has evolved through an intensive, evidence-based approach to learning and improvement through pilot-project implementation, impact assessment studies and consultations with national and international experts. The programme has been reviewed and accepted by the Government of Goa. The programme is currently being implemented in 781 Government Primary Schools in Goa.

Key features of Mulyavardhan:

* In consonance with the Constitution of India, National Curriculum Framework (NCF) 2005, RTE Act 2009, and NCERT’s Education for Values in Schools. A Framework document (2012)
* Comprehensive approach to education for values, incorporating the cognitive (knowing and thinking), affective (feeling, valuing, committing) and behavioural aspects of values
* Well-defined conceptual framework for students to acquire democratic values and related attitudes and competencies in an enabling school climate
* Incorporates age-appropriate structured classroom activities for development of values, attitudes & competencies, aligned to scholastic learning outcomes related to development of cognitive and social skills
* Impacts entire school ethos and teaching & learning practices

Framework:

Mulyavardhan aims to help students develop the values/attitudes and competencies necessary for democratic citizenship, in an enabling school environment. The values/attitudes and competencies are derived through a framework. At the core lie values enshrined in the Constitution of India. These values define the Programme’s goals and also guide its educational practices and implementation processes. An understanding of the core values leads to the identification of desirable values and attitudes of a democratic citizen. These values/attitudes are placed in the school-education context in Mulyavardhan. Related to the values/attitudes are certain competencies, which are critical for helping students to become knowledgeable, responsible, caring and contributing members of society.

Implementation strategy:

Phased approach: SMF suggests a phased approach to implementation of Mulyavardhan in schools, starting with capacity-building of potential teacher-trainers, who will gain experience of conducting Mulyavardhan class activities and then train other teachers with support from SMF.

In year 1 of a project and years thereafter, regular conduct of structured class activities is suggested. In years 2 and 3 and thereafter, school-wide activities and connections with scholastic teaching and learning are suggested.

Scaling strategy: For scaling of the programme in large school bodies, SMF suggests that the programme is first implemented in selected schools, and through this experience, a cadre of experienced Mulyavardhan teacher-trainers is created for taking the programme to a larger number of schools.

SMF support:

SMF offers support in three main areas to government and private school-bodies keen on implementing Mulyavardhan:

* Capacity building
* Educational materials
* Project management

Capacity-building:

SMF conducts Mulyavardhan orientation and capacity-building workshops for potential teacher-trainers, headmasters and education officials. SMF also provides materials and guidance for conduct of Mulyavardhan teacher-training workshops by SMF-trained teachers. Technology-based support mechanisms for teachers are being developed.

Educational materials:

At appropriate stages, the following educational materials are provided to schools/teachers:

* Grade-wise classroom activity books for teachers
* Grade-wise workbooks for students
* Reference guide for teachers
* Guidebook for headmasters
* All the above materials are currently available in Marathi. Materials are being developed in English and Hindi. Technology-based dissemination of educational materials is being explored.
funding_pattern: Not specified
title: Value Education Scheme (Mulyavardhan)

description:
Horticulture is the major activity in the State as it occupies more than 60% of the total cropped area. The small and fragmented holdings coupled with high cost of labour have increased the cost of cultivation with corresponding reduction in income in recent years. It is, therefore proposed to support this sector with various incentives and assistance so as to encourage youth to take up production of various horticulture crops.

Short title and commencement.— (i) The scheme shall be called “Development of Horticulture 2018”.

(ii) The scheme shall come into force with retrospective effect from 1-4-2018 and shall remain in force till it is withdrawn. The beneficiaries who have applied after 1-4-2018 shall be considered to avail benefits as per the new pattern of assistance under this scheme.

(iii) The scheme shall cover all Talukas of the State of Goa.

procedures.step_description: The interested cultivators shall submit their application in the prescribed format along with Krishi Card abstract copy.

Farmers shall take up the work/plantation as per the guidelines of the scheme with proper recommended spacing. They shall ensure to use quality planting material from the registered Government or private nurseries. In case planting material such as banana, pineapple, flower crops etc. is purchased from local farmer the same shall be approved/certified for its quality and genuineness by the respective Zonal Agricultural Officer.\nUpon completion the farmer shall submit bills and receipts along with necessary annexure as per the scheme.

The project/site will be inspected by Zonal Agricultural Officer or his representative and recommend for release of subsidy as per the pattern of assistance/guidelines and forward to the concerned District Agricultural Officer (DAO) for sanction.
The District Agricultural Officer shall examine the claim and accord expenditure sanction for subsidy within his powers.
The District Agricultural Officer shall draw and disburse the subsidy.

funding_pattern: as per the pattern of assistance/guidelines
title: Development of Horticulture, 2018

description:
The major constraint in the field of dairy development in the State of Goa is the lack of green fodder for the Milch animals. The nutritive value of feed and fodder has a significant bearing on productivity of livestock; as such a provision of the Green Fodder for feeding Milch animals is very essential. Keeping this in view fodder development has been made an integral part of Livestock development.

In the present scheme the subsidy is Rs. 65,000/- per hectare, and provide irrigation assistance to take up the perennial green fodder cultivation having water source. Provision have also been made for purchase of implements like water pump, PVC pipes, sprinklers etc. with 75% subsidy on the total cost.

In order to cultivate Perennial Green Fodder farmers can avail tussocks free of cost from Government Livestock Farm, Dhat, Mollem, Cattle Breeding Farm, Copardem, and Fodder Seed Production Farm, Kalay.
funding_pattern: Subsidy of Rs. 65,000/- per hectare. 75% subsidy on implements like water pump, PVC pipes, and sprinklers.
title: Scheme for incentive to Green Fodder Cultivation for Perennial and Seasonal Fodder Development in the State (Amended) 2017-18

description: The Goa Stray Cattle Management Scheme, 2013 (Modified) aims to address the stray cattle menace in Goa by making the scheme open to all Municipalities, Panchayats, AWOs, Goshalas, and Civic & Consumer Forums (CCF). The scheme focuses on removing stray cattle from public areas, transporting them safely to cattle pounds, providing proper care, and making farmers responsible for their animals.  It includes provisions for impounding, housing, medical care, and a pattern of assistance with financial details for various components. The scheme also outlines procedures for releasing impounded cattle, including fines and auctioning options for unclaimed animals.

procedures.step_description: AWOs, Goshalas, and CCFs apply for grants through local bodies.
Local bodies recommend applications to the Directorate of Animal Husbandry & Veterinary Services.
Grants are disbursed electronically to the local body upon approval.
Stray cattle are impounded and transported to cattle pounds.
Owners can claim impounded cattle by paying fines.
Unclaimed cattle may be auctioned.

funding_pattern: 90% government grant, 10% institutional funds (with possible 5% waiver based on merit and financial condition). Specific amounts are detailed for various components like vehicle purchase, salaries, shed construction, cattle feeding, veterinary care, and other expenses.
title: The Goa Stray Cattle Management Scheme, 2013 (Modified)

description:
Goatery Scheme — Assistance for Goat Rearing.
Introduction.— Goats play an important role in the rural economy at national level. More than 70 percent of the landless agricultural labourers, marginal and small farmers of rural India rear them. The socio-economic value of goat rearing as compared to other livestock species has been immense for the poor farmers. Goats are the most potential source of meat production with minimum housing requirements. Goats can sustain on sparse vegetation and extreme climatic conditions. They are more efficient feed converters. Apart from providing meat, it is also a source of high quality milk, manure and hide. Goat farming will provide employment opportunities to unemployed rural youths and farmers thereby providing supplementary income to improve their living standards. The advantages of the goat farming are:
1. They are prolific breeders with shorter generation interval.
2. A goat can be bred as early as 8-9 months of age and can kid twice in a year. They produce 1-2 kids in each kidding.
3. Goat farming requires low initial investment on setting up the unit.
4. Goat meat (chevon) is most nutritious with low fat and has better energy value. The dressing percentage in goats is around 50%.
5. The meat is generally acceptable, delicious and of higher demand which is consumed by all communities in India and has no religious taboo.
6. Goat’s milk being alkaline has medicinal value & hence recommended for patients with peptic ulcers, allergic eczemas, jaundice, acidosis and insomnia. It also contains high phosphates which can supplement the phosphorus deficient vegetarian diet. Goat milk contains selenium, an essential trace mineral that supports the immune system.
7. Goat manure is widely used as fertilizer for agriculture farms and gardens.
8. Goat farming provides quick returns since the marketable weight of goat can be achieved within a period of 12 months.
9. There is good demand from domestic as well as export market for goat meat.
Objective.— (1) To provide financial assistance for purchase and rearing of indigenous breeds of Goats which are suitable to the climatic conditions of the State of Goa. (2) To augment the meat production in the State & to make the State self sufficient in meat production. (3) To provide subsidiary occupation to unemployed youth and women. (4) To motivate farmers to undertake scientific, intensive and semi intensive Goat farming. (5) To upgrade local stock to make Goat farming profitable.
Eligibility.— (1) Any farmer residing for minimum 5 years in the State. (2) Should have undergone training in Goat Management. 3. Should have goat shed on height of approx. 1.5 mts. from ground admeasuring minimum 30 sq. mts. with flooring of bamboo/ /matti and roof of tiles/sheets/straw.
Documents to be produced.— (a) Residence Certificate (minimum 5 years residence). (b) Aadhar consent form. (c) Certificate of training in Goat Management. (d) Documents indicating the ownership of land in Form No. I & XIV or copy of lease deed for 3 years or NOC from the Land Owner for 3 years in case of Tenants for the purpose of Goat farming. (e) Passport size photograph of the applicant. (f) On approval of Application, a Bond and Affidavit has to be submitted as per Annexure I & II of the scheme.
title: Goatery Scheme
funding_pattern: One time subsidy will be released at the rate of 75%

procedures.step_description: Approach the Veterinary Officer/Assistant Director of Department of A.H. & V.S. of the respective area for Registration Form.
